headline.main: Battling for Bullion

docs.snippet: In the high stakes struggle between Newmont Mining of Denver and South Africa's AngloGold for control of Australia's largest gold producer, Normandy Mining, Barrick Gold of Canada has so far been a silent spectator.    But Barrick has the highest mar
docs.lead_paragraph: In the high stakes struggle between Newmont Mining of Denver and South Africa's AngloGold for control of Australia's largest gold producer, Normandy Mining, Barrick Gold of Canada has so far been a silent spectator. But Barrick has the highest market value and the strongest balance sheet of any gold producer in the world. And last week, it completed a $2.3 billion acquisition of the Home stake Mining Company of Walnut Creek, Calif., a combination that made Barrick the world's second-largest producer, after AngloGold and just ahead of Newmont.

docs.abstract: Barrick Gold reports second-quarter net profit of $66 million, down from $72 million year earlier; photo (S)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Miner's Profit Falls

docs.snippet: Barrick Gold, the Toronto-based gold producer, reported a drop in second-quarter net profit, to $66 million, or 17 cents a share, from $72 million, or 18 cents a share, a year earlier, mostly because of higher energy costs in the western United State
docs.lead_paragraph: Barrick Gold, the Toronto-based gold producer, reported a drop in second-quarter net profit, to $66 million, or 17 cents a share, from $72 million, or 18 cents a share, a year earlier, mostly because of higher energy costs in the western United States and a lower gold price. The chief executive, Randall Oliphant, above, said higher costs at the El Indio mine in Chile and Goldstrike in Nevada, coupled with lower interest income, would probably result in earnings for the year ''at the lower end'' of earlier estimates of 70 to 75 cents a share. Cash costs for the second quarter rose to $162 an ounce from $144. The average realized price dropped to $340 an ounce from $360, still well above prevailing market prices, thanks to an active hedging policy. Second-quarter output rose to 958,400 ounces from 899,000 ounces. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline.main: Newmont Mining to Cut Work Force by 5%

docs.snippet: Feeling the effects of a slumping gold price, the Newmont Mining Corporation, North America's biggest gold miner, said today that it would trim its work force by 5 percent from last year's levels, one of several cost-reduction measures in the works.
docs.lead_paragraph: Feeling the effects of a slumping gold price, the Newmont Mining Corporation, North America's biggest gold miner, said today that it would trim its work force by 5 percent from last year's levels, one of several cost-reduction measures in the works. Newmont, which reported a loss for the first quarter of $5.5 million, or 3 cents a share, said it would cut workers in the United States and overseas by 5 percent, to about 3,000 through a voluntary early retirement program and through attrition.

headline.main: ANGLOGOLD POSTS LOSS

docs.snippet: Anglogold, the world's biggest gold miner, announced a $16.9 million loss for the fourth quarter, after the company's decision to write down the value of some of its struggling mines. Anglogold is trying to reposition itself in the gold industry by u
docs.lead_paragraph: Anglogold, the world's biggest gold miner, announced a $16.9 million loss for the fourth quarter, after the company's decision to write down the value of some of its struggling mines. Anglogold is trying to reposition itself in the gold industry by unloading its least profitable ventures, and the write-down, which totaled nearly $93 million, is a reminder of the reasons behind that strategy. With its huge global operation and its high overhead costs, Anglo is poorly suited to manage some of the low-margin mines in its stable, especially with the gold price stagnant and showing little promise of an upswing. The write-down offset a 9 percent rise in operating profit to $114 million. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

headline.main: Gold Believers Put Rationality to Test

docs.snippet: WHEN people look for irrational investors these days, the first place they turn is the dot-com world. But the hurly-burly carnival ring of the stock market is not the only place where irrationality is king.    In the far-away world of commodities are
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN people look for irrational investors these days, the first place they turn is the dot-com world. But the hurly-burly carnival ring of the stock market is not the only place where irrationality is king. In the far-away world of commodities are some investors who are also experts at praying for good things to happen. And they have been doing it longer than the dot-com world has been around.

headline.main: FIFTH BRITISH GOLD SALE

docs.snippet: The Bank of England sold 25 tons of British reserve gold for $285.25 a troy ounce, a disappointing result which sent the gold price lower. The auction is the latest in the Bank of England's move to modernize its portfolio -- replacing bullion holding
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bank of England sold 25 tons of British reserve gold for $285.25 a troy ounce, a disappointing result which sent the gold price lower. The auction is the latest in the Bank of England's move to modernize its portfolio -- replacing bullion holdings with dollars, euros and yen. Analysts said the results of the fifth auction in the first set of gold sales, aimed at reducing British gold reserves to 300 tons from 715 tons, was disappointing.

headline.main: Becoming Bolder With Bets on Gold

docs.snippet: WHEN Barrick Gold, the most successful hedger in the mining business, curtails the practice, that's news. And when the same company gives up some of its locked-in gains to make a bet that gold will rally, something has changed in this precious-metal
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Barrick Gold, the most successful hedger in the mining business, curtails the practice, that's news. And when the same company gives up some of its locked-in gains to make a bet that gold will rally, something has changed in this precious-metal market. So what is Barrick up to? Barrick, based in Toronto, says it is trying to satisfy its shareholders, some of whom think hedging is a sin, although the practice allowed Barrick to produce record earnings last year as the price of gold first hit a 20-year low and then finished 1999 up just 40 cents on ounce.

docs.abstract: Barrick Gold, once industry's leading proponent of hedging as a protection against falling prices, says it will reduce amount of gold still in ground it has already sold for future delivery by a third; has contracts outstanding to deliver 17.9 million ounces, 22 percent of its current reserves, figure it plans to cut to 15 percent of reserves by end of 2003; will also cut use of other hedging devices; plans to invest $2 billion over next five years to build four mines in Peru, Argentina and Australia, stepping up its gold output 1.2 million ounces a year (M)

headline.main: Barrick to Cut Gold Hedging and Build 4 More Mines

docs.snippet: Barrick Gold, once the gold industry's leading proponent of hedging as a protection against falling prices for metal, said today that it would reduce its forward sales position -- the amount of gold still in the ground that it has already sold for fu
docs.lead_paragraph: Barrick Gold, once the gold industry's leading proponent of hedging as a protection against falling prices for metal, said today that it would reduce its forward sales position -- the amount of gold still in the ground that it has already sold for future delivery -- by one-third. Right now, Barrick, which is based in Toronto, has outstanding contracts to deliver 17.9 million ounces, or 22 percent of its current reserves. The company said today that it would cut that figure to 12 million ounces, or 15 percent of reserves, by the end of 2003. The use of other hedging devices, like options and variable-price sales contracts, will also be cut, the company said.

docs.abstract: Barrick Gold Crop reports 47 percent decline in first-quarter net income, to $46 million from $87 million; production slipped by 7.6 percent and costs climbed to $263 per ounce from $246 (S)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Gold Profit Drops

docs.snippet: The Barrick Gold Corporation, the Toronto-based gold producer, reported a 47 percent decline in first-quarter net income, with lower output and higher production costs offsetting a slight rise in prices. Income was $46 million, or 9 cents a share, a
docs.lead_paragraph: The Barrick Gold Corporation, the Toronto-based gold producer, reported a 47 percent decline in first-quarter net income, with lower output and higher production costs offsetting a slight rise in prices. Income was $46 million, or 9 cents a share, a decline down from the $87 million, or 16 cents a share, recorded a year earlier. Production slipped by 7.6 percent and costs climbed to $263 an ounce from $246. The average realized gold price was $329 an ounce, up from $320. Barrick said that for the first time, it had sold half of its mines' output on the spot market, where the price averaged $290. Its hedging program realized an average price of $365. Bernard Simon (NYT)

headline.main: The Price of Gold Is Shining. Hedging of Gold Is Not.

docs.snippet: THE performance of Barrick Gold's stock shows that the sentiment of the gold market has swung sharply against hedging.    Hedgers and anti-hedgers have been battling for years. Hedgers lock in the current price of gold, plus a premium, by borrowing g
docs.lead_paragraph: THE performance of Barrick Gold's stock shows that the sentiment of the gold market has swung sharply against hedging. Hedgers and anti-hedgers have been battling for years. Hedgers lock in the current price of gold, plus a premium, by borrowing gold, selling it and then investing the proceeds. They say this is good management and smart protection against a price decline. Anti-hedgers are more bullish on gold, saying hedging prevents a company from reaping the full benefit of a price rise. They talk much less about the downside risk.

headline.main: Gold Has Good Days As Other Assets Fall

docs.snippet: THE bad news that has engulfed financial markets in the last year or so has been a salve for gold mutual funds. Over the last five quarters, no sector of the fund universe has done better.    Consolidation in the mining industry has helped lower cost
docs.lead_paragraph: THE bad news that has engulfed financial markets in the last year or so has been a salve for gold mutual funds. Over the last five quarters, no sector of the fund universe has done better. Consolidation in the mining industry has helped lower costs, but fundamentals in the gold business are much unchanged. Share prices have been driven higher by the instability and uncertainty caused by factors like the downturn in the global economy, the events of Sept. 11, the fall of Enron and concern about the stability of the Japanese financial system.

headline.main: Some Japanese Are Hoarding Gold

docs.snippet: While Japan has had the world's fastest-growing major stock market this year and the yen has jumped nearly 3 percent against the dollar in the last month, a small but growing number of Japanese investors are preparing for the worst and hoarding gold.
docs.lead_paragraph: While Japan has had the world's fastest-growing major stock market this year and the yen has jumped nearly 3 percent against the dollar in the last month, a small but growing number of Japanese investors are preparing for the worst and hoarding gold. With limits looming on bank deposit insurance, banks tottering under bad debts and the government printing money in an effort to create inflation, sales of gold are expected to come close to quadrupling this quarter, compared with the period last year, according to the World Gold Council, an industry group.

headline.main: Gold Is Looking Better, but Just How Much Better?

docs.snippet: THIS is not an easy time for gold bulls -- or gold bears.    Bulls have reason to think that they are gaining the upper hand after years of disappointment. Gold is back up to around $300 an ounce. Fears of gold-selling by European central banks appea
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is not an easy time for gold bulls -- or gold bears. Bulls have reason to think that they are gaining the upper hand after years of disappointment. Gold is back up to around $300 an ounce. Fears of gold-selling by European central banks appear to be contained, and producers are reining in their passion for hedging, which for years had helped to depress gold prices.

docs.abstract: Barrick Gold Corp will sell half of its 2002 gold production on spot market, breaking string of 14 years in which it has hedged on all its output; has argued in past that forward sales contracts, options and other hedging techniques protect company's furture profit in face of uncertain gold price; Newmont Mining Corp, on other hand, has no-hedging and believes that hedging amounts to bet against gold, limiting possible profits as well as possible losses, making gold stocks less attractive to investors; AngloGold, another hedger, has also indicated that it will make more use of spot market (M)

headline.main: In a Big Switch, Barrick to Sell Some Gold on Spot Market

docs.snippet: The Barrick Gold Corporation said today that it planned to sell half of its 2002 gold production on the spot market -- the first time in 14 years that it has not hedged, or locked in prices in advance, on all its output.     A spirited debate has rag
docs.lead_paragraph: The Barrick Gold Corporation said today that it planned to sell half of its 2002 gold production on the spot market -- the first time in 14 years that it has not hedged, or locked in prices in advance, on all its output. A spirited debate has raged in the industry for a decade over the wisdom of hedging, and Barrick's new policy is an important change of direction for a major producer.

docs.abstract: Gold producers are split on whether to hedge against drop in price of gold now that Newmont Mining Corp is poised to become world's biggest gold producer through its pending acquisition of Normandy Mining Ltd; Newmont is firmly in antihedging camp; company believes hedging is bet against icon, dampening profits of mines and making gold stock less attractive; Barrick Gold sees Newmont's antihedging pitch as attempt to distract investors' attention from Newmont's shortcomings, including higher production costs and heavier debt burden; graph (M)

headline.main: Gold Producers Are Split On Whether to Hedge

docs.snippet: Now that the Newmont Mining Corporation is poised to become the world's biggest gold producer, through its pending acquisition of Normandy Mining Ltd., the stage seems set to resolve an argument that has raged among members of the industry for the la
docs.lead_paragraph: Now that the Newmont Mining Corporation is poised to become the world's biggest gold producer, through its pending acquisition of Normandy Mining Ltd., the stage seems set to resolve an argument that has raged among members of the industry for the last decade: whether to hedge against a drop in the price of their product. Newmont, based in Denver, is firmly in the antihedging camp. The company believes hedging is a bet against an icon, dampening the profits of mines and making gold stocks less attractive.

docs.abstract: Board of AngloGold give shareholders of Normandy Mining another week to consider its $2.24 billion cash-and-stock offer, which has drawn just 6.5 percent of Normandy so far; Newmont Mining says documents connected to its takeover plan for Normandy have been approved by SEC (M)

headline.main: Australia Gold Miner Is Still Up for Grabs

docs.snippet: One of the most drawn-out takeover battles in the global mining industry was extended further today after the board of AngloGold  gave shareholders of Normandy Mining, Australia's largest gold producer, another week to consider its plan.    AngloGold
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most drawn-out takeover battles in the global mining industry was extended further today after the board of AngloGold gave shareholders of Normandy Mining, Australia's largest gold producer, another week to consider its plan. AngloGold's $2.24 billion cash- and-stock deal had drawn just 6.5 percent of Normandy by the end of the day, AngloGold said. Explaining the last-minute deferral, AngloGold's chief executive, Robert M. Godsell, said he wanted to give shareholders ''the fullest opportunity to consider the offer.'' The offer, which was scheduled to close today, will now lapse on Jan. 18. AngloGold is a unit of Anglo American of London.

docs.lead_paragraph: SENSING a renewed appetite among Americans, a small army of foreigners is invading the United States with new kinds of gold investments. Ten small and midsized Canadian gold producers have been listed on the American Stock Exchange in the last year. docs.snippet: While Japan has had the world's fastest-growing major stock market this year and the yen has jumped nearly 3 percent against the dollar in the last month, a small but growing number of Japanese investors are preparing for the worst and hoarding gold.
docs.lead_paragraph: While Japan has had the world's fastest-growing major stock market this year and the yen has jumped nearly 3 percent against the dollar in the last month, a small but growing number of Japanese investors are preparing for the worst and hoarding gold. With limits looming on bank deposit insurance, banks tottering under bad debts and the government printing money in an effort to create inflation, sales of gold are expected to come close to quadrupling this quarter, compared with the period last year, according to the World Gold Council, an industry group.

headline.main: Gold Is Looking Better, but Just How Much Better?

docs.snippet: THIS is not an easy time for gold bulls -- or gold bears.    Bulls have reason to think that they are gaining the upper hand after years of disappointment. Gold is back up to around $300 an ounce. Fears of gold-selling by European central banks appea
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is not an easy time for gold bulls -- or gold bears. Bulls have reason to think that they are gaining the upper hand after years of disappointment. Gold is back up to around $300 an ounce. Fears of gold-selling by European central banks appear to be contained, and producers are reining in their passion for hedging, which for years had helped to depress gold prices.

docs.abstract: Barrick Gold Corp will sell half of its 2002 gold production on spot market, breaking string of 14 years in which it has hedged on all its output; has argued in past that forward sales contracts, options and other hedging techniques protect company's furture profit in face of uncertain gold price; Newmont Mining Corp, on other hand, has no-hedging and believes that hedging amounts to bet against gold, limiting possible profits as well as possible losses, making gold stocks less attractive to investors; AngloGold, another hedger, has also indicated that it will make more use of spot market (M)

headline.main: In a Big Switch, Barrick to Sell Some Gold on Spot Market

docs.snippet: The Barrick Gold Corporation said today that it planned to sell half of its 2002 gold production on the spot market -- the first time in 14 years that it has not hedged, or locked in prices in advance, on all its output.     A spirited debate has rag
docs.lead_paragraph: The Barrick Gold Corporation said today that it planned to sell half of its 2002 gold production on the spot market -- the first time in 14 years that it has not hedged, or locked in prices in advance, on all its output. A spirited debate has raged in the industry for a decade over the wisdom of hedging, and Barrick's new policy is an important change of direction for a major producer.

docs.abstract: Gold producers are split on whether to hedge against drop in price of gold now that Newmont Mining Corp is poised to become world's biggest gold producer through its pending acquisition of Normandy Mining Ltd; Newmont is firmly in antihedging camp; company believes hedging is bet against icon, dampening profits of mines and making gold stock less attractive; Barrick Gold sees Newmont's antihedging pitch as attempt to distract investors' attention from Newmont's shortcomings, including higher production costs and heavier debt burden; graph (M)

headline.main: Gold Producers Are Split On Whether to Hedge

docs.snippet: Now that the Newmont Mining Corporation is poised to become the world's biggest gold producer, through its pending acquisition of Normandy Mining Ltd., the stage seems set to resolve an argument that has raged among members of the industry for the la
docs.lead_paragraph: Now that the Newmont Mining Corporation is poised to become the world's biggest gold producer, through its pending acquisition of Normandy Mining Ltd., the stage seems set to resolve an argument that has raged among members of the industry for the last decade: whether to hedge against a drop in the price of their product. Newmont, based in Denver, is firmly in the antihedging camp. The company believes hedging is a bet against an icon, dampening the profits of mines and making gold stocks less attractive.

docs.abstract: Board of AngloGold give shareholders of Normandy Mining another week to consider its $2.24 billion cash-and-stock offer, which has drawn just 6.5 percent of Normandy so far; Newmont Mining says documents connected to its takeover plan for Normandy have been approved by SEC (M)

headline.main: Australia Gold Miner Is Still Up for Grabs

docs.snippet: One of the most drawn-out takeover battles in the global mining industry was extended further today after the board of AngloGold  gave shareholders of Normandy Mining, Australia's largest gold producer, another week to consider its plan.    AngloGold
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most drawn-out takeover battles in the global mining industry was extended further today after the board of AngloGold gave shareholders of Normandy Mining, Australia's largest gold producer, another week to consider its plan. AngloGold's $2.24 billion cash- and-stock deal had drawn just 6.5 percent of Normandy by the end of the day, AngloGold said. Explaining the last-minute deferral, AngloGold's chief executive, Robert M. Godsell, said he wanted to give shareholders ''the fullest opportunity to consider the offer.'' The offer, which was scheduled to close today, will now lapse on Jan. 18. AngloGold is a unit of Anglo American of London.

headline.main: Dollar's Fall Pushes Gold Above $450

docs.snippet: Gold rose above $450 an ounce for the first time in more than 16 years, driven by investors looking for an alternative to the American currency.
docs.lead_paragraph: With the dollar hitting a third straight day of record lows against the euro on Thursday, gold rose above $450 an ounce for the first time in more than 16 years, driven by investors looking for an alternative to the American currency. ''Gold bulls should be dancing in the street,'' Barclays Capital said in an investment note. Gold, which is priced in dollars, has risen by about 13 percent in the past two months.

headline.main: Report Heightens Pollution Dispute at Indonesian Bay

docs.snippet: A government panel presented a bitterly fought-over report on Monday showing that sediment in the equatorial bay where the world's biggest gold producer, Newmont Mining Corporation, deposited mine waste is polluted with significant levels of arsenic
docs.lead_paragraph: A government panel presented a bitterly fought-over report on Monday showing that sediment in the equatorial bay where the world's biggest gold producer, Newmont Mining Corporation, deposited mine waste is polluted with significant levels of arsenic and mercury. But the panel found the water quality met Indonesian standards. The report, written by more than a dozen technical specialists, found that fish from the bay were laced with enough arsenic to make them dangerous for consumption, particularly for children. It recommended that the Health Ministry ''look into arsenic poisoning'' by conducting more tests on villagers who have complained of rashes, lumps, breathing difficulties and dizziness. It also said the government should consider moving the villagers from an area it ''categorized as possessing high risks for human health.''

headline.main: A South African City Loses Luster After the Gold Rush

docs.snippet: Half a century ago, after gold was found on a nearby farm, this sprawling city of malls and neat row houses erupted from the flat plains of what is now the Free State province of South Africa. Built by the mining magnate Ernest Oppenheimer above the
docs.lead_paragraph: Half a century ago, after gold was found on a nearby farm, this sprawling city of malls and neat row houses erupted from the flat plains of what is now the Free State province of South Africa. Built by the mining magnate Ernest Oppenheimer above the vast, and seemingly limitless, riches underground, Welkom was a homestead for South Africa's cash-flush white miners. In its heyday in the 1970's, when Welkom produced 35 percent of South Africa's gold, the city bustled with new-money flash, and represented, perhaps more than any city in South Africa, apartheid's divisions. Mr. Oppenheimer built a world-class racecar track, gardens, parks, Olympic-length pools and broad avenues for white miners, while black miners languished in single-sex hostels.

headline.main: Johannesburg Journal; There's Gold in Those Sand Piles (So They're Vanishing)

docs.snippet: As landfills go, Charles Symons said one cloudless recent afternoon, this has been one of the best. He was gazing fondly at a 120-foot-high pile of yellow sand. Its south face was under patient assault by a front-end loader; its backside besieged by
docs.lead_paragraph: As landfills go, Charles Symons said one cloudless recent afternoon, this has been one of the best. He was gazing fondly at a 120-foot-high pile of yellow sand. Its south face was under patient assault by a front-end loader; its backside besieged by a man toting a high-pressure fire hose. They and others have been working here, around the clock, since 1997. By next May, the sand pile, once a veritable mountain stretching hundreds of yards in every direction, will be gone. Mr. Symons's company will be a little richer. And, for better or worse, Johannesburg's storied history will be one sand pile poorer.

headline.main: Pricing Gold but No Longer Standing on British Tradition

docs.snippet: Another piece of the British empire crumbled yesterday when no one raised or lowered the Union Jack to set the international price of gold.    Instead of meeting twice a day, as they have for almost 85 years, in the oak-paneled offices of the venerab
docs.lead_paragraph: Another piece of the British empire crumbled yesterday when no one raised or lowered the Union Jack to set the international price of gold. Instead of meeting twice a day, as they have for almost 85 years, in the oak-paneled offices of the venerable merchant banking group NM Rothschild & Sons in London's financial district, four precious-metals traders -- three in London and one in Paris -- fixed the gold price on a telephone conference call, basing the decision on their latest readings of supply and demand.

docs.lead_paragraph: INDUSTRIAL commodity prices are surging, lifted by the rebound of the global economy. Gold is also a highflier, helped some by stronger economies but more by the fall in the value of the dollar. headline.main: Gold Prospectors Don't Always Head for the Hills

docs.snippet: Gold Prospectors.
docs.lead_paragraph: Remember ''The Treasure of the Sierra Madre''? That classic John Huston film was perhaps the ultimate tale of an obsession with the gold in them thar hills. Well, perhaps today's remake could be titled ''The Treasure of the Golden Junkyard.'' Because, apparently, there's an awful lot of gold lying around, just waiting to be picked up, in them thar basements, Dumpsters, dresser drawers, even mouths. All it takes is a little incentive to look for it -- an incentive like, say, a soaring gold price.

headline.main: Finding Comfort (and New Friends) in Gold

docs.snippet: For some, gold is a way of life. For others, it is a hedge against inflation.
docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S a splendid spring day in Connecticut's horse country and James E. Sinclair, perhaps the best-known gold speculator of his era, is sitting before his trading terminal, contemplating the upward thrust of gold on his trader's chart. The sun, bursting through the bay windows, catches the glint of gold that is everywhere in Mr. Sinclair's home office: on the coins near his computer, on his chunky Rolex watch, on the rings on three of his fingers, on the cuff links on his monogrammed shirt, and -- could it be? -- a hint of it in his one working eye.

docs.lead_paragraph: GOLD makes a few people rich and a lot of people giddy. King Tutankhamen went to his grave with a trove of it. Francisco Pizarro, the explorer, pillaged for it. John Maynard Keynes, the economist, railed against it. Neil Young wrote songs about it. Nobody, besides butchers, rhapsodizes about pork bellies. And with the price of bullion rising -- in December, it topped $500 an ounce for the first time in nearly 25 years -- mutual fund investors have been bitten by the gold bug, too. In the first 10 months of 2005, a net $2.3 billion flowed into precious-metals funds, which tend to be dominated by gold miners' stocks. That inflow was up 50 percent over the full-year figure for 2004. Just a few years ago, some investors were fleeing these funds; they had net outflows in 2000 and 2001.

headline.main: Gold, Again, Becomes a Shield Against the Unknown

docs.snippet: Gold is supposed to be a destination for scared money, but as the credit crunch intensified, this presumed haven lost value along with many other assets.
docs.lead_paragraph: GOLD is supposed to be a destination for scared money, but as the credit crunch intensified last month, this presumed haven lost value along with many other assets. Only after the worst of the crisis had passed did traders return to gold, sending its price sharply higher. The metal has gained about $80 an ounce, or 12 percent, since mid-August, around the time the stock market reached a trough. While share prices have since had ups and downs, gold's ascent has been nearly uninterrupted.

headline.main: Gold Prospectors Don't Always Head for the Hills

docs.snippet: Gold Prospectors.
docs.lead_paragraph: Remember ''The Treasure of the Sierra Madre''? That classic John Huston film was perhaps the ultimate tale of an obsession with the gold in them thar hills. Well, perhaps today's remake could be titled ''The Treasure of the Golden Junkyard.'' Because, apparently, there's an awful lot of gold lying around, just waiting to be picked up, in them thar basements, Dumpsters, dresser drawers, even mouths. All it takes is a little incentive to look for it -- an incentive like, say, a soaring gold price.

headline.main: Finding Comfort (and New Friends) in Gold

docs.snippet: For some, gold is a way of life. For others, it is a hedge against inflation.
docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S a splendid spring day in Connecticut's horse country and James E. Sinclair, perhaps the best-known gold speculator of his era, is sitting before his trading terminal, contemplating the upward thrust of gold on his trader's chart. The sun, bursting through the bay windows, catches the glint of gold that is everywhere in Mr. Sinclair's home office: on the coins near his computer, on his chunky Rolex watch, on the rings on three of his fingers, on the cuff links on his monogrammed shirt, and -- could it be? -- a hint of it in his one working eye.

docs.lead_paragraph: GOLD makes a few people rich and a lot of people giddy. King Tutankhamen went to his grave with a trove of it. Francisco Pizarro, the explorer, pillaged for it. John Maynard Keynes, the economist, railed against it. Neil Young wrote songs about it. Nobody, besides butchers, rhapsodizes about pork bellies. And with the price of bullion rising -- in December, it topped $500 an ounce for the first time in nearly 25 years -- mutual fund investors have been bitten by the gold bug, too. In the first 10 months of 2005, a net $2.3 billion flowed into precious-metals funds, which tend to be dominated by gold miners' stocks. That inflow was up 50 percent over the full-year figure for 2004. Just a few years ago, some investors were fleeing these funds; they had net outflows in 2000 and 2001.

headline.main: Three Harbors in a Rough Quarter

docs.lead_paragraph: IF Mick Jagger and Keith Richards had been fund managers, they might have written ''Gimme Shelter'' about the first quarter of 2008. As the mortgage mess buffeted nearly every segment of the stock market, many a manager probably wished for protection from the storm. A few managed to find it, and they were shielded as much by their funds' charters -- guidelines governing what they should and should not buy -- as their own smarts. Many of the top performers either kept a good chunk of their shareholders' money somewhere besides stocks or camped out in a quirky market corner. A Fund That's Meant for Mom

headline.main: Driving to the Gold Rush

docs.snippet: Leaving jobs at global giants, small miners are striking out for Mexico’s Sierra Madre mountains.
docs.lead_paragraph: In these mountains, where conquistadors once gouged gold from open veins in the mountainside, the hardened gold miner of film lore is giving way to a new breed of prospector: geologists and engineers, armed with sophisticated equipment and millions of investor dollars. Largely American and Canadian, they toiled for global mining giants for years. But, now that the price of gold is near record highs, they are leaving their companies, raising capital to start their own prospecting start-ups and heading for Mexico. On Tuesday, an ounce of gold hit $929.30, up from $665 a year ago. Back in 1980, oil shock and economic gloom drove the price to $875 an ounce; that would be more than $2,000 today.

headline.main: Gold, Again, Becomes a Shield Against the Unknown

docs.snippet: Gold is supposed to be a destination for scared money, but as the credit crunch intensified, this presumed haven lost value along with many other assets.
docs.lead_paragraph: GOLD is supposed to be a destination for scared money, but as the credit crunch intensified last month, this presumed haven lost value along with many other assets. Only after the worst of the crisis had passed did traders return to gold, sending its price sharply higher. The metal has gained about $80 an ounce, or 12 percent, since mid-August, around the time the stock market reached a trough. While share prices have since had ups and downs, gold's ascent has been nearly uninterrupted.

headline.main: Gold Fever: Pondering The Causes

docs.snippet: Investors turn to gold when they fear the return of big inflation and as a way to stick out their tongues at the so-called elites who run the economy.
docs.lead_paragraph: It is part religion, part politics. It is a way to voice a lack of confidence in the central banks of the world and a yearning for the world as it used to be. It is an investment that historically made sense when inflation was rampant, and yet it is soaring while the Federal Reserve frets about the threat of deflation.

docs.snippet: Motorola will restructure in January, but there’s still a gap between the company’s current and break-up value.

headline.main: Testing the Limits Of Loose Money

docs.snippet: The Fed risks blowing bubbles around the world, with potentially damaging effects.

byline.original: By IAN CAMPBELL and ROB COX

docs.lead_paragraph: Sound monetary policy begins at home. The prime goal of the Federal Reserve is to nurture a healthy national economy. But it would be nave to ignore the influence that Fed policy has on markets around the globe. And at present the Fed risks blowing global bubbles, with potentially damaging effects. The bubble blowing begins with beliefs about the Fed's thinking. In the last few weeks the understanding has become that the Fed favors a second round of quantitative easing. The impacts have been many: a sharp fall in the dollar against the euro, yen and many emerging market currencies; appreciating bonds and equities in both the developed world and emerging markets; a record nominal gold price; and a jump in commodity prices.

headline.main: The Crowd Around the Gold Counter

docs.snippet: Many skeptics wonder why investors are still flocking to gold after such a run-up in value.
docs.lead_paragraph: Gold evokes emotions from investors like few other investable assets. Whether it is increasing or decreasing in value, people usually have an interest in it beyond its intrinsic value as an investment. ''If I went outside and talked about gold, everyone would have an opinion on it, including the taxi drivers,'' said Jason Toussaint, managing director of the World Gold Council, a group whose mission is to stimulate demand for gold. ''Anyone past the age of 4 knows about gold. It brings out a lot of people of opinions.''

headline.main: Why We May See Gold Hit $5,000

docs.snippet: Sure, gold is trading at about $1,200 today. But $5,000 is plausible.

byline.original: By MARTIN HUTCHINSON and CHRISTOPHER HUGHES

docs.lead_paragraph: It sounds like a gold bug's dream. But looking back to the last inflation-adjusted peak price in 1980, it's far from impossible that the gold price could soon go above $5,000 an ounce. The potential level of a new high can be estimated in several ways. Based on consumer price inflation, the peak of $875 an ounce in 1980 is equivalent to about $2,300 today, almost twice the current gold price. But there's a case for taking account of economic expansion as well as price inflation. The world's economic output has increased about sixfold since 1980. Scale up the peak 30 years ago by that multiple, and the gold price could top out at around $5,300.

docs.abstract: Roberta Smith reviews artworks from late 1950s and 1960s from collection of Robert and Ethel Scull on view at Acquavella Galleries in Manhattan; photos (M)

headline.main: Appetite for New and Next New

docs.snippet: Robert and Ethel Scull’s collection represents one of the most influential shopping sprees in postwar American art.

multimedia.caption: The Scull Collection
multimedia.credit: Robert and Ethel Scull amassed one of the world’s most impressive collections of Pop Art before selling most of it. A portion is currently on view at Acquavella Galleries.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Robert and Ethel Scull amassed one of the world’s most impressive collections of Pop Art before selling most of it. A portion is currently on view at Acquavella Galleries.

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe we don't need to be reminded that the American art of the late 1950s and '60s moved with ferocious speed. Those were the glory days, we've been taught, repeatedly and indelibly. Still, the momentum is especially -- and poignantly -- palpable in ''Robert & Ethel Scull: Portrait of a Collection,'' at Acquavella Galleries in Manhattan. The show, which was proposed to Acquavella by the writer Judith Goldman, contains 37 paintings, sculptures and drawings, along with some photo documentation. It rushes from Abstract Expressionist paintings like Willem de Kooning's whiplash ''Police Gazette'' of 1955 to the Earthworks that Michael Heizer began cutting in the floor of the Nevada desert in 1968. In between are efforts by a string of impressive names: paintings by Jasper Johns, James Rosenquist, Myron Stout, Larry Poons, Andy Warhol and Frank Stella; sculptures by Mark di Suvero, John Chamberlain and Claes Oldenburg, Walter De Maria and Robert Morris.

headline.main: No Coattail Effect In Gold's Surge

docs.snippet: While doubts about the economies of the United States and Europe have made gold more expensive, they have also hurt stock prices — including those of some mining companies.
docs.lead_paragraph: IF you bought a precious-metals fund at the start of this year because you expected stock market turbulence and thought gold would be a refuge, your foresight was impressive. Your returns? Not as much. Gold rose 14.3 percent, to $1,624 an ounce, in the first nine months of the year, including 8.2 percent in the third quarter. The price has been underpinned by persistent doubts about the economic and financial health of the United States and Europe and the measures that governments and central banks might have to take to put things right.

headline.main: How Three Funds Tried to Turn Back the Tide

docs.snippet: Throughout the summer, mutual funds looked for havens — typical ones like gold, and less common ones like short sales — as they tried to shield their investors from the market’s huge losses.
docs.lead_paragraph: STOCKS sank in nearly every corner of the market in the third quarter. The major American and European indexes? Down. Emerging markets like Brazil, Russia, India and China? Also down. But managers of several of the quarter's better-performing funds found ways to protect their shareholders from the full pain of the slump, even when they didn't eke out gains. These managers sought out typical havens, like discount retailers and gold stocks, and less common ones, like short sales.

headline.main: Shares Down Moderately on U.S. Debt Talks

docs.snippet: Stocks closed lower, but not at their lowest point of the day, as investors focused on the debt ceiling talks in Washington.
docs.lead_paragraph: The lack of a deal to raise the debt limit in the United States hung over the financial markets on Monday, unsettling investors because of the uncertainty but not provoking a major reaction in bond or stock prices. House Republicans and Senate Democrats were readying competing plans in an effort to avoid a federal default next week. Republicans were trying to sell to their rank and file a two-step plan that would allow the federal debt limit to immediately rise by about $1 trillion and tie a second increase next year to more deficit reductions.

headline.main: Gold Fever: Pondering The Causes

docs.snippet: Investors turn to gold when they fear the return of big inflation and as a way to stick out their tongues at the so-called elites who run the economy.
docs.lead_paragraph: It is part religion, part politics. It is a way to voice a lack of confidence in the central banks of the world and a yearning for the world as it used to be. It is an investment that historically made sense when inflation was rampant, and yet it is soaring while the Federal Reserve frets about the threat of deflation.

headline.main: In Motorola Split, New Chapter

docs.snippet: Motorola will restructure in January, but there’s still a gap between the company’s current and break-up value.

byline.original: By ROBERT CYRAN and ROBERT COLE

docs.lead_paragraph: Motorola promised in early 2008 to break itself up under pressure from activists. It's taken a long while, but come January, that day finally arrives. Given the pace of Motorola's restructuring, that sounds like plenty of time for investors to have ferreted out hidden treasure. Yet there's still a gap between Motorola's current and break-up value.

headline.main: Risky Bonds, Light Protections

docs.snippet: Inadequate bondholder provisions in several recent deals indicated that many risky bonds lacked protections.

byline.original: By AGNES CRANE  and MARTIN HUTCHINSON

docs.lead_paragraph: Investors feel better when risky bonds come with flak jackets. Drive-by deals, so named for skipping the conventional road-show route in favor of a one-day turnaround, do not give investors much time to ensure they are protected. Shoddier bondholder provisions in several recent, often rushed, deals indicate many are not.

headline.main: Testing the Limits Of Loose Money

docs.snippet: The Fed risks blowing bubbles around the world, with potentially damaging effects.

byline.original: By IAN CAMPBELL and ROB COX

docs.lead_paragraph: Sound monetary policy begins at home. The prime goal of the Federal Reserve is to nurture a healthy national economy. But it would be nave to ignore the influence that Fed policy has on markets around the globe. And at present the Fed risks blowing global bubbles, with potentially damaging effects. The bubble blowing begins with beliefs about the Fed's thinking. In the last few weeks the understanding has become that the Fed favors a second round of quantitative easing. The impacts have been many: a sharp fall in the dollar against the euro, yen and many emerging market currencies; appreciating bonds and equities in both the developed world and emerging markets; a record nominal gold price; and a jump in commodity prices.

headline.main: The Crowd Around the Gold Counter

docs.snippet: Many skeptics wonder why investors are still flocking to gold after such a run-up in value.
docs.lead_paragraph: Gold evokes emotions from investors like few other investable assets. Whether it is increasing or decreasing in value, people usually have an interest in it beyond its intrinsic value as an investment. ''If I went outside and talked about gold, everyone would have an opinion on it, including the taxi drivers,'' said Jason Toussaint, managing director of the World Gold Council, a group whose mission is to stimulate demand for gold. ''Anyone past the age of 4 knows about gold. It brings out a lot of people of opinions.''

headline.main: Why We May See Gold Hit $5,000

docs.snippet: Sure, gold is trading at about $1,200 today. But $5,000 is plausible.

byline.original: By MARTIN HUTCHINSON and CHRISTOPHER HUGHES

docs.lead_paragraph: It sounds like a gold bug's dream. But looking back to the last inflation-adjusted peak price in 1980, it's far from impossible that the gold price could soon go above $5,000 an ounce. The potential level of a new high can be estimated in several ways. Based on consumer price inflation, the peak of $875 an ounce in 1980 is equivalent to about $2,300 today, almost twice the current gold price. But there's a case for taking account of economic expansion as well as price inflation. The world's economic output has increased about sixfold since 1980. Scale up the peak 30 years ago by that multiple, and the gold price could top out at around $5,300.

docs.abstract: Roberta Smith reviews artworks from late 1950s and 1960s from collection of Robert and Ethel Scull on view at Acquavella Galleries in Manhattan; photos (M)

headline.main: Appetite for New and Next New

docs.snippet: Robert and Ethel Scull’s collection represents one of the most influential shopping sprees in postwar American art.

multimedia.caption: The Scull Collection
multimedia.credit: Robert and Ethel Scull amassed one of the world’s most impressive collections of Pop Art before selling most of it. A portion is currently on view at Acquavella Galleries.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Robert and Ethel Scull amassed one of the world’s most impressive collections of Pop Art before selling most of it. A portion is currently on view at Acquavella Galleries.

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe we don't need to be reminded that the American art of the late 1950s and '60s moved with ferocious speed. Those were the glory days, we've been taught, repeatedly and indelibly. Still, the momentum is especially -- and poignantly -- palpable in ''Robert & Ethel Scull: Portrait of a Collection,'' at Acquavella Galleries in Manhattan. The show, which was proposed to Acquavella by the writer Judith Goldman, contains 37 paintings, sculptures and drawings, along with some photo documentation. It rushes from Abstract Expressionist paintings like Willem de Kooning's whiplash ''Police Gazette'' of 1955 to the Earthworks that Michael Heizer began cutting in the floor of the Nevada desert in 1968. In between are efforts by a string of impressive names: paintings by Jasper Johns, James Rosenquist, Myron Stout, Larry Poons, Andy Warhol and Frank Stella; sculptures by Mark di Suvero, John Chamberlain and Claes Oldenburg, Walter De Maria and Robert Morris.

headline.main: In a Focus On Gold, History Repeats Itself

docs.snippet: Newt Gingrich’s call for a commission to examine a return to the gold standard has a familiar ring. Ronald Reagan did the same more than 30 years ago.
docs.lead_paragraph: As it was in 1980, could it be again in 2012? The 1980 presidential election was fought by a Democratic incumbent weakened by a poor economy amid worries that the United States had lost its ability to compete in the world. Gold prices had risen to unprecedented levels as the election approached, and the Republican nominee hinted he might propose a return to a gold standard.

headline.main: No Coattail Effect In Gold's Surge

docs.snippet: While doubts about the economies of the United States and Europe have made gold more expensive, they have also hurt stock prices — including those of some mining companies.
docs.lead_paragraph: IF you bought a precious-metals fund at the start of this year because you expected stock market turbulence and thought gold would be a refuge, your foresight was impressive. Your returns? Not as much. Gold rose 14.3 percent, to $1,624 an ounce, in the first nine months of the year, including 8.2 percent in the third quarter. The price has been underpinned by persistent doubts about the economic and financial health of the United States and Europe and the measures that governments and central banks might have to take to put things right.

headline.main: How Three Funds Tried to Turn Back the Tide

docs.snippet: Throughout the summer, mutual funds looked for havens — typical ones like gold, and less common ones like short sales — as they tried to shield their investors from the market’s huge losses.
docs.lead_paragraph: STOCKS sank in nearly every corner of the market in the third quarter. The major American and European indexes? Down. Emerging markets like Brazil, Russia, India and China? Also down. But managers of several of the quarter's better-performing funds found ways to protect their shareholders from the full pain of the slump, even when they didn't eke out gains. These managers sought out typical havens, like discount retailers and gold stocks, and less common ones, like short sales.

headline.main: Shares Down Moderately on U.S. Debt Talks

docs.snippet: Stocks closed lower, but not at their lowest point of the day, as investors focused on the debt ceiling talks in Washington.
docs.lead_paragraph: The lack of a deal to raise the debt limit in the United States hung over the financial markets on Monday, unsettling investors because of the uncertainty but not provoking a major reaction in bond or stock prices. House Republicans and Senate Democrats were readying competing plans in an effort to avoid a federal default next week. Republicans were trying to sell to their rank and file a two-step plan that would allow the federal debt limit to immediately rise by about $1 trillion and tie a second increase next year to more deficit reductions.

headline.main: In a Focus On Gold, History Repeats Itself

docs.lead_paragraph: As it was in 1980, could it be again in 2012? The 1980 presidential election was fought by a Democratic incumbent weakened by a poor economy amid worries that the United States had lost its ability to compete in the world. Gold prices had risen to unprecedented levels as the election approached, and the Republican nominee hinted he might propose a return to a gold standard.
